article:
In logic, 'false' is a truth value or a nullary logical connective. In a truth-
functional system of propositional logic it is one of two postulated truth
values, along with its negation, truth. Jennifer Fisher, On the Philosophy
of Logic, Thomson Wadsworth, 2007, ISBN 0-495-00888-5, [http://books.google.com/books?id=k8L_YW-
lEEQC&pg=PT27 p. 17.] Usual notations of the false are 0 (especially in
Boolean logic and computer science) and the up tack symbol . Willard
Van Orman Quine, Methods of Logic, 4th ed, Harvard University Press, 1982, ISBN
0-674-57176-2, [http://books.google.com/books?id=liHivlUYWcUC&pg=PA34 p.
34.]

Another approach is used for several formal theories (for example,
intuitionistic propositional calculus) where the false is a propositional
constant (i.e. a nullary connective) , the truth value of this constant
being always false in the sense above. George Edward Hughes and D.E. Londey,
The Elements of Formal Logic, Methuen, 1965,
[http://books.google.com/books?id=JbwOAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA151 p. 151.] Leon
Horsten and Richard Pettigrew, Continuum Companion to Philosophical Logic,
Continuum International Publishing Group, 2011, ISBN 1-4411-5423-X,
[http://books.google.com/books?id=w_abLTXIFkcC&pg=PA199 p.
199.] Graham Priest, An Introduction to Non-Classical Logic: From If
to Is, 2nd ed, Cambridge University Press, 2008, ISBN 0-521-85433-4,
[http://books.google.com/books?id=rMXVbmAw3YwC&pg=PA105 p. 105.]
headings: In classical logic and Boolean logic
